facts.text: Mortgage bond dated 8th April 1927 (21st Chaitra 1334 Fasli), written and engrossed at plaintiffs' house in village Chakla Maulanagur.
Executants (mortgagors from Chandpur) put signatures on the bond on 12th April 1927.
Bond registered on 12th April 1927 at Katihar before Registering Officer.
Due date for payment in the mortgage bond: 6th March 1928.
Eight payments made by defendants in part satisfaction of debt: Rs.300 on 21 Jan 1928; Rs.75 on 5 Jun 1929; on 8 Mar 1931; 3 Apr 1931; two in May 1932; 25 Jul 1934; 15 May 1936. Total Rs.780-9-0.
Suit instituted on 4th March 1940 as Title Mortgage Suit No.7 of 1940 for enforcement of simple mortgage by sale of mortgaged property.

Subordinate Judge of Purnea decree dated 27 Feb 1942: Bond not legally attested, hence not mortgage; money decree personal against first party defendants; limitation not barred due to payments under s20 Limitation Act.
Defendants (first party) appealed to Patna High Court as F.A. No.47 of 1942; no appeal or cross-objection by plaintiffs.
Patna High Court (Fazl Ali CJ and Beevor J) judgment dated 17 Mar 1944: Bond duly attested and enforceable as mortgage; suit within time; affirmed trial decree as no cross-appeal by plaintiffs.
Appeal to Judicial Committee on special leave granted 2 Aug 1946, transferred to Supreme Court.
Attesting witnesses: Sunderlal, Matukdhari Prasad, Dwarka Prasad, Nanak Prasad (scribe); all from Chakla Maulanagur.
P.W.1 Sunderlal: Signed bond at plaintiffs' house on same day written; attestation same day.
Matukdhari Prasad: Bond written, signed by executants, attested by witnesses on same date.
Defendant No.1 Sant Lall: Executants signed at Katihar before registration, reached by train 9-10 am.
No endorsements of payments on bond; no acknowledgment in handwriting or signed by debtors before suit.
Paragraph 15 written statement of defendants 1-3 admits payments but claims more payments not credited.
Amended plaint: Added personal remedy saved by payments; no averment of written acknowledgment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the mortgage bond was legally attested under the law.
Whether the suit for personal money decree was barred by limitation under Article 116 Limitation Act, or saved by payments under section 20 Limitation Act.
Whether acknowledgment of payment under s20 must exist prior to institution of suit.
Whether High Court or Supreme Court can grant mortgage decree despite no appeal/cross-objection by plaintiffs under Order 41 Rule 33 CPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if bond effective as mortgage, no personal money decree unless suit within Article 116 Limitation Act (6 years from due date).
Payments do not extend limitation as not acknowledged in handwriting or signed by payer as per s20 proviso.
Bond not legally attested; attesting witnesses signed before execution on 12th April.

respondent_arguments.text: Bond duly attested; suit within time as mortgage enforcement.
High Court can pass mortgage decree under Order 41 Rule 33 CPC despite no appeal/cross-objection, based on its finding on attestation; invite SC to do same.

court_reasoning.text: For personal decree if not mortgage, governed by Art 116 (6 yrs from due date); suit beyond 6 yrs unless extended by s20.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Framing as mortgage suit does not extend limitation for personal relief.

court_reasoning.text: S20 requires payment within limitation period AND acknowledgment in handwriting/signed by payer; acknowledgment must exist before suit filing, as limitation determined at plaint date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Written statement admission post-suit cannot save; no prior acknowledgment; plaint must allege existing facts.

court_reasoning.text: Payments proved by admission but no signed acknowledgment before suit; suit barred for personal decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subordinate Judge wrong to rely on written statement as acknowledgment under s20.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence: Bond written 8 Apr at plaintiffs' house; attesting witnesses (local) signed then; executants signed 12 Apr at Katihar before registration; thus attested before execution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court wrong; 'written' distinguished from execution; probabilities support signing before execution.

holdings.text: Suit for personal money decree barred by limitation; no valid acknowledgment under s20 before suit.
Bond not legally attested as attesting witnesses signed before execution by mortgagors.
Acknowledgment under s20 proviso must be in existence prior to institution of suit.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs limitation for personal decree and extension by part payments with acknowledgment; suit barred if no prior acknowledgment.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to grant relief despite no cross-appeal; plaint must state limitation exemption grounds.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds suit barred by limitation for personal money decree as no written acknowledgment of payments existed before filing; bond not properly attested; money decree not justified.

key_quotes.text: "Unless, therefore, there is acknowledgment in the required form, the payment by itself is of no avail."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on s20 Limitation Act requirements.

key_quotes.text: "the acknowledgment, whether made before or after the period of limitation, must be in existence prior to the institution of the suit."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Decisive on timing of acknowledgment for limitation.

key_quotes.text: "the word written could be interpreted to mean execution as well."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's erroneous interpretation of witness testimony on attestation.
